section-block.rac_essential-question: What do we do during different seasons?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Big Book: Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy

section-block.rac_book_summary: In this bright book filled with colorful pictures, you will find out about the weather, nature, and each of the four seasons.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about what they know about seasons. Discuss what season it is now, and what season is coming next.
Sing to the tune of “If You’re Happy and You Know It”: What are the seasons of the year? (clap, clap) Winter, spring, summer, fall. Now you’ve named them all. These are the seasons of the year.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy by Jane Brocket.
Scout loves informational books like this one. They help him learn about the world.
I want you to think about this question as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What happens to plants and animals in each season?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What starts to appear through the soil in spring?
Can someone show me the soil in the pictures?
What happens to animals in spring?

Brightly colored flowers attract buzzing insects in summer. This bee seems to like the pink flower. Show me how you buzz like a bee. What sound starts buzz and bee? Can you find that letter on the page?
Look at the fall colors on these pages. What is happening on some trees and bushes? What has the spider done?
Does the spider web look different from the web on page 19? Why?
Look at the picture. What is missing from these trees? Is this the way trees look in winter where we live? (MB)
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What happens to plants and animals in each season?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk Then, use Equity Sticks to pick 2 or 3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Tiny new plants appear in spring.
Bees buzz around flowers in summer.
Leaves turn colors in the fall.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about seasons as children watch and listen. Say:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: English speakers often use the phrases in spring, in summer, in fall, and in winter when they talk about the seasons. Let’s try to use these phrases when we talk about seasons.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do leaves turn colors in the fall or the winter?
Leaves turn colors in the f____ . (fall)
Leaves turn colors in the fall.
What else happens to leaves in the fall?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Learning about seasons ties into children’s interest in what is going on around them every day. Encourage children to talk about what they see outside. For example, do they notice more or fewer birds at different times of the year as the weather changes? Help children make connections between the classroom and the world outdoors.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Make Connections
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion about things that happen during the different seasons, and connect stories from your own life to the information in the book. For example, tell about when flowers grew in a neighborhood garden or when you were caught in snow during winter. Encourage children to make their own connections to the information in the book.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look for the make connections Mind Builder as we revisit Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy by Jane Brocket.
This book is about seasons. Clifford loves the seasons. His favorite season is summer!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s review the book and pictures and look for the make connections Mind Builder.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: In this book, we will learn about seasons and how things change from season to season.
Let’s name the seasons together: spring, summer, fall, winter.
The book says we can tell what the season is by looking at the weather, the light, and nature. Let’s make a connection from the book to what’s happening around us.
What season is it now? Does our weather today go with a picture on these pages? (MB)
Look at the picture of the puddle. Say the words splish, splash, splosh out loud. They sound like playing in a puddle! Have you ever played in a puddle? What do you remember about it? (MB)
Let’s make a connection between these pictures of fruits and vegetables and the foods we like. Do you enjoy eating apples, cabbage, or squash? (MB)
Sometimes in winter it’s nice to stay inside under a cozy blanket. What else is nice to do in winter?

section.rac_body-text: Remind children to follow classroom rules as they transition to Extended Play. Invite children to describe what the weather is like today and tell how that relates to the season. First discuss what the current season is and what the weather is usually like. If possible, have children observe the sky outside and describe it. Invite children to describe how it felt to be outside. What connections can they make to the book?
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about seasons. Help children build vocabulary and increase sentence complexity.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Making connections is a key skill for preschool children to develop. Teachers can support children by providing them with opportunities to make observations and then letting them draw or make charts about what they observed. Teachers can also ask children questions about what they observed. (Resourcesforearlylearning.org/Educators/Connections)

section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children that sorting things into groups, or categorizing, can help them think about what they read. For example, they can sort the different stages of a tree’s life cycle into the season each stage occurs, such as tree buds in spring. Have volunteers take turns grouping other stages of a tree’s cycle by season.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy by Jane Brocket. As we reread, we will categorize, or group, different kinds of weather by the seasons they go with.
Scout loves putting things in categories because it helps him understand the world around him.
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is the weather like in each season?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. During reading, use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
If the weather for seasons where you are is different from what’s in the book, invite students to talk about the seasons where you are.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The pictures on these pages show two kinds of spring weather. Can you name them? What does the sky look like in each kind of weather? How might you feel in each kind?
What does the sky look like here? How do you think your skin would feel in summer weather?
How does the sky change when it thunders? Why do you look for shelter during a thunderstorm?

This page talks about fall weather. Do crunchy and crispy make you think of rainy weather or clear days with dry leaves on the ground? How about blustery and blowy? How would it feel to have a gust of wind blowing on you?
What does the sky in winter look like? What kinds of weather are there in winter?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is the weather like in each season?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to pick 2 or 3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: In spring, weather may be rainy.
In summer, the weather is hot.
In winter, there might be snow.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about seasons. Invite children to increase sentence complexity by adding words that label or describe people, places, things, or actions.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is the weather in summer hot or cold?
In summer, the weather is h____ . (hot)
In summer, the weather is hot.
Which season do you think is the best? Why?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschool children are able to recognize patterns. The ability to sort and categorize will help them with literacy tasks (e.g., sorting words with the same sounds) and other domains. Providing children with the opportunities to sort items or to tell what is the same and different will help them develop these skills.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion about all they have learned about Earth this month and about seasons this week. What new words have they learned about the seasons?
Sing to the tune of “The Farmer in the Dell”:
section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I know the seasons all, I know the seasons all, Winter, spring, summer, fall, I know the seasons all.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Changing Seasons. It has informational text on a poster.
Scout loves to look at information about changing seasons, especially if he has nuts stored up for winter!
Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy and The Changing Seasons each focus on the seasons of the year. Let’s see if we can find any connections between the two.
As we read, let’s think about how the texts connect to this week’s concept question:
What do we do during different seasons?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the poem on the back, then use the prompts to read and discuss the poster together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions, and pass the microphone to each speaker.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can point to the picture of winter? What are the children doing? How is the winter picture different from the other seasons?
Is your winter like this? (MB)
Who can point to the picture of spring? What does the girl plant?
How is this picture like the one in the book?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show page 4 of the big book.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can point to the summer picture? What is the family doing?
Who can point to the picture that shows fall? Does it look like the pictures in the book? How?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show pages 18–19 of the big book.

section.rac_body-text: Help children use new words by playing a game of “I Spy.” Have them listen to clues and guess which season you are “spying.” You might say, I spy people building snow forts. What season is it? After a few rounds, let children make up their own clues, using their new words as they describe what they spy.
Provide a writing prompt about seasons and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children enhance their learning when they can make connections between texts. Help them notice if, for example, the same author has written two or more books. Discuss whether books share a genre or whether they have a similar topic. By making these connections, children become more engaged with reading and develop their memory skills.

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children take turns to show and tell what they like to do in one season. Start by saying, In winter, I like to skate, and act it out.
Invite students to show good ways to make the transition between circle time and other activities. Give positive feedback when they do this responsibly.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact Rainy, Sunny, Blowy, Snowy by Jane Brocket.
This book is informational, which means that it tells about real things. Scout loves reading about real things, especially in winter, when he can cuddle up indoors.
This week we read all about the seasons of the year. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
What can you do in different seasons?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: In spring, children can run around and play outside. Run around is a phrase people use when they go all over the place. Show me how you might run around outside.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: In summer, bees buzz around flowers. Can you show me how a bee flies from flower to flower?
Why would you have bare feet on hot days during summer?
Why might you wear flip-flops?
How are warm-weather and cold-weather clothes different?
The book says that fall is “time to carve pumpkins.”
Have you ever made a funny face on a pumpkin? Let’s make faces like carved pumpkins! (MB)
Imagine that you are at home with a cup of hot cocoa on a cold day during winter. Show me how you would sip it. What are the letter sounds for day?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to discuss the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What can you do in different seasons?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk Then, use Equity Sticks to pick 2 or 3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: In spring, I can fly a kite.
In summer, I can go barefoot.
In fall, I can carve pumpkins.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about seasons and share their work. Encourage them to use common phrases in their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can you go barefoot in summer or winter?
In summer, I can go b________ . (barefoot)
In summer, I can go barefoot.
What would you do if the weather never changed?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Recognizing cognates can help Spanish speakers learn English more quickly. As you discuss different activities for different seasons, point out that the word activity has the Spanish cognate actividad.
